parsetree.*:
<root><template><title>Command</title><part><name>Comments</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value> arma3 </value></part><part><name>Game name</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>1.16</value></part><part><name>Game version</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>gr1</name>=<value> Variables </value></part><part><name>GROUP1</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value> Performs strict comparison between var1 and var2 and returns [[true]] if equal, otherwise [[false]]. Strict means that it would check that both arguments are of the same data type and then compare the values.<br><br>
Some differences between [[isEqualTo]] and [[==]]:
* It performs case sensitive comparison on [[String]]s
* It doesn't throw error when comparing different types, i.e. ("eleven" [[isEqualTo]] 11)
* It can compare [[Array]]s, [[Script]]s and [[Boolean]]s ([[alive]] [[player]] [[isEqualTo]] [[true]])
* It can compare non-existent game objects ([[grpNull]] [[isEqualTo]] [[grpNull]])
* It can compare [[Namespace]]s (''As of Arma 3 v1.47'')
* It is slightly faster than [[==]], especially when comparing [[String]]s <br><br>
<template lineStart="1"><title>Informative </title><part><name index="1"/><value> A compiled code is not equal to the same compiled code made final: <code>_a <template><title>=</title></template> [[compile]] "123"; _b <template><title>=</title></template> [[compileFinal]] "123"; _a [[isEqualTo]] _b; // false</code> </value></part></template>
<template lineStart="1"><title>Warning </title><part><name index="1"/><value> When comparing [[Array]]s, if an array contains [[nil]] element, the comparison will return [[false]]. For example:<br>
<code>[[private]] _array1 <template><title>=</title></template> [1,[[nil]],2];
[[private]] _array2 <template><title>=</title></template> [1,[[nil]],2];
_array1 [[isEqualTo]] _array2 // false</code>
<u>UNLESS</u> the compared arrays are the same array:
<code>[[private]] _array1 <template><title>=</title></template> [1,[[nil]],2];
[[private]] _array2 <template><title>=</title></template> _array1;
_array1 [[isEqualTo]] _array2 // true</code>
See: [[BIS_fnc_areEqual]] vs. [[BIS_fnc_areEqualNotNil]]</value></part></template></value></part><part><name>DESCRIPTION</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value> val1 '''isEqualTo''' val2 </value></part><part><name>SYNTAX</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value> val1: [[Anything]] </value></part><part><name>PARAMETER1</name>=<value>
</value></part><part><name>p2</name>=<value> val2: [[Anything]] </value></part><part><name>PARAMETER2</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name index="5"/><value> [[Boolean]] </value></part><part><name>RETURNVALUE</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________
		  
</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <code>_arr1 = [1,[2,[3]]];
_arr2 = [1,[2,[3]]];
[[if]] (_arr1 [[isEqualTo]] _arr2) [[then]] {[[hint]] "Arrays match!"}</code> </value></part><part><name>EXAMPLE1</name>=<value>

		  
</value></part><part><name>x2</name>=<value> <code>[[if]] (a [[isEqualTo]] b) [[then]] {[[hint]] "a is equal to b"};
[[if]] !(a [[isEqualTo]] b) [[then]] {[[hint]] "a is not equal to b"};</code> </value></part><part><name>EXAMPLE2</name>=<value>

____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="6"/><value> [[isEqualTypeAll]], [[isEqualTypeAny]], [[isEqualType]], [[isEqualTypeParams]], [[isEqualTypeArray]], [[typeName]], [[Operators]], [[in]], [[find]], [[set]], [[resize]], [[switch]], [[a == b]] </value></part><part><name>SEEALSO</name>=<value>

</value></part></template>

<comment><!-- CONTINUE Notes -->
</comment><dl class="command_description">
<dd class="notedate">Posted on July 19, 2014 - 19:48 (UTC)</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:AgentRevolution|AgentRev]]</dt>
<dd class="note">
The behavior of "var1 [[isEqualTo]] var2" is pretty much equivalent to "var1 [[in]] [var2]", plus the ability to compare arrays, and slightly better performance.
</dd>
</dl>

<dl class="command_description">
<dd class="notedate">Posted on December 3, 2014 - 13:11 (UTC)</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:Tajin|Tajin]]</dt>
<dd class="note">
Simply put, "isEqualTo" is a binary comparison. Therefor it is very fast but only accepts '''100%''' identical matches. In some other languages this is known as "&#61;&#61;&#61;" instead of "&#61;&#61;".
</dd> 
</dl>
<comment><!-- DISCONTINUE Notes -->
</comment>
<comment><!-- CONTINUE Notes -->
</comment><dl class="command_description">
<dd class="notedate">Posted on November 3, 2016 - 02:39 (UTC)</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:Dedmen|Dedmen]]</dt>
<dd class="note">
When comparing with nil result is Nothing.
"nil isEqualTo player" returns "Nothing" instead of expected "false"
<code>diag_log [nil isEqualTo player];</code>
Will print "[bool]"
<code>diag_log (str (nil isEqualTo player)) + "test";</code>
Will throw Generic error in expression 
"+: Type Nothing, expected Number,Array,String,Not a Number"
</dd>
</dl>
